newsitem.title: FINLAND: Helsinki ends down but brokers hope worst is over.
newsitem.headline: Helsinki ends down but brokers hope worst is over.

text.p: Shares closed sharply lower, led by a decline on Wall Street while Helsinki was closed for Easter, but the bourse managed to weather the storm better than many in Europe, brokers said.

The HEX general index fell 2.22 percent to 2,784.45 after hitting 2,760.04 earlier -- down over three percent -- and the FOX derivatives and portfolio benchmark closed at 970.83 points, down 2.54 percent.
"We've taken this (downward correction) quite calmly," one broker said.
Telcommunications group Nokia lost 8.50 markka or 2.85 percent to close at 290.00 markka, accounting for 30 percent of 605 million markka volume, which was livelier than last week.
"Tomorrow will be a better day," said another broker, pointing to expectations ahead of the U.S. market open that Wall Street would stabilise.
"This morning nobody wanted to buy anything -- in the afternoon there was demand in quite a few shares," one broker said. "I don't see any major panic."
The banking sector and Merita fell most sharply, with the banking sub-index down almost six percent and Merita down 1.00 markka or 5.88 percent at 16.00, brokers said.
"Fears of higher interest rates have again hit banking shares," one broker said.
Brokers said the outlook depended fully on U.S. markets. "There are no fundamental reasons for this decline," said one.
